JUDGES: Angelika Nußberger;Dean Spielmann;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in LOC . He was represented before ORG by Ms K. Petrusová , a lawyer practising in GPE .
On DATE the applicant , who was working as a car mechanic , was dismissed from his job with immediate effect for underperforming in his duties .
On DATE he brought an action requesting the court to find the dismissal invalid and the work contract still in effect .
On DATE the first hearing was held before ORG . As the parties failed to reach an agreement and requested a report concerning the service of the dismissal , the hearing was adjourned .
On DATE the applicant asked the court to summon his father and grandfather as witnesses .
On DATE he informed the court that he had changed his legal counsel .
On DATE the judge of ORG invited the applicant to indicate the whereabouts of the witnesses he had proposed to be heard . On DATE the applicant provided the information .
On DATE the ORG , whose assistance was requested because of its proximity to the witnesses , held a hearing and heard CARDINAL witnesses .
On DATE the applicant applied to supplement his action by claiming compensation for unpaid salary from DATE to DATE .
On DATE the applicant sent a letter to the president of ORG in which he complained that the court had not ordered a new hearing to conclude the proceedings .

On DATE the vice - president of ORG apologised for the delays and explained that they were caused by , among other things , the workload of the judge , difficulties with obtaining the report from the post office , and the assistance of ORG .
On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s application to supplement his action .
On DATE the applicant again complained to the presidents of ORG and ORG about the length of the proceedings .
On DATE the vice - president of ORG apologised to the applicant ; however , he found his complaint justified only with regard to the period from DATE .
On DATE ORG rendered a judgment in which it found the dismissal invalid as it had not been served in accordance with LAW . The judgment was served on the applicant on DATE .
On DATE a judge of ORG declined to rule on the defendant ’s appeal as ORG had not fully decided on the action .
On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal complaining that the proceedings before the lower courts had been lengthy .

On DATE , following a hearing , ORG supplemented the first judgment and determined that the work contract was still valid . The judgment was served on the applicant on DATE , following his complaint of CARDINAL DATE .
On DATE the applicant supplemented his constitutional appeal .
On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s constitutional appeal . It held that the proceedings had indeed been lengthy but at that stage it would be unreasonable and redundant to interfere .

On DATE ORG , following a hearing , upheld the first judgment and changed the supplementary judgment by holding that in the light of the wrongful dismissal the further validity of the working contract was self - evident .
On DATE both parties filed an appeal on points of law .
On DATE ORG quashed the second part of the judgment , remitted this issue to ORG and dismissed the remainder of the appeals .
On DATE ORG , following a hearing , upheld the supplementary judgment of ORG . The judgment became final on DATE .

On DATE the applicant claimed compensation under PERSON no . MONEY for non - pecuniary damage arising from the excessive length of the above proceedings , which he evaluated at CARDINAL NORP korunas ( CZK ) ( approx . CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) .
On DATE the applicant supplemented his initial claim by asking for compensation for pecuniary damage incurred as legal costs .

In a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG acknowledged , referring to the case - law of the ORG , that the proceedings , which had lasted DATE , had been unreasonably lengthy and had suffered from administrative malpractice within the meaning of LAW of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . ORG concluded , however , that the acknowledgment of the delays represented sufficient satisfaction for non - pecuniary damage . As for pecuniary damage , the ORG rejected the claim for lack of any causal link .
On DATE the applicant brought a civil action for compensation in respect of pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage against the Ministry .

On DATE ORG dismissed the action finding that apart from during the period from DATE the courts had acted in reasonable time . The court further reasoned that labour disputes should be decided quickly owing to their consequences on the personal and social life of the claimants , but underlined that in the present case the invalidity of the dismissal had been pronounced already in DATE . The overall length was only slightly beyond the appropriate length and thus the acknowledgement of the violation of the applicant ’s right represented sufficient satisfaction .

On DATE ( served on CARDINAL March ) ORG upheld this judgment . It reiterated that , in the light of the actual complexity of the case , the length of the proceedings had been inappropriate but only to a small extent .

The relevant domestic law and practice concerning remedies for the excessive length of judicial proceedings are set out in the ORG ’s decision in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL- CARDINAL , DATE ) .
